options: f grows at most as fast as g
f grows at least as fast as g
f grows exactly as fast as g
f grows strictly slower than g
questions.correctAnswer: f grows at least as fast as g
questions.explanation: Ω is the lower bound: f(n) = Ω(g(n)) means ∃ C > 0 such that |f(n)| ≥ C|g(n)| for large n. Big-O is 'at most', Big-Ω is 'at least', Big-Θ is 'exactly'.
Θ is the tight bound: f = Θ(g) iff f = O(g) AND f = Ω(g). This means C₁|g| ≤ |f| ≤ C₂|g| — f is sandwiched between two constant multiples of g.
Little-o is stricter than Big-O. f = o(g) means f grows strictly slower — the ratio f/g → 0. For example, n = o(n²) because n/n² = 1/n → 0.

questions.prompt: Comparison-based sorting requires Ω(n log n) comparisons. This means:
options: Every sorting algorithm takes exactly n log n steps
No comparison-based sorting algorithm can use fewer than cn log n comparisons for some c > 0
Merge sort is the fastest possible
Quick sort is always O(n log n)
questions.correctAnswer: No comparison-based sorting algorithm can use fewer than cn log n comparisons for some c > 0
questions.explanation: Ω(n log n) is an information-theoretic lower bound: n! possible orderings require log₂(n!) ≈ n log n comparisons to distinguish. No algorithm can beat this — merge sort achieves this bound, so it's optimal.
Õ(g(n)) means f(n) = O(g(n)·log^ℓ(n)) for some ℓ. It's used when logarithmic factors are practically irrelevant — log(10⁶) ≈ 20, so absorbed into the constant for practical purposes.

questions.prompt: Monte Carlo error is O_P(1/√n). The 'P' means:
questions.explanation: O_P is Big-O in probability. It means the random variable X_n/a_n is bounded in probability — the error doesn't exceed M/√n with high probability. Since Monte Carlo produces random estimates, the deterministic Big-O doesn't apply directly.
Asymptotic equivalence: f ~ g means lim |f/g| = 1. This is the strongest statement — f and g become proportionally identical for large n. For example, n² + n ~ n² because (n² + n)/n² = 1 + 1/n → 1.
f ~ g (ratio → 1) implies f = Θ(g) (tight bound), which implies both f = O(g) and f = Ω(g). So ~ is strongest, then Θ, then O and Ω individually.

questions.prompt: If f(n) = 3n² + 5n + 2, which statements are true?
questions.explanation: f = 3n² + 5n + 2. Upper bound: |f| ≤ 10n² for large n → f = O(n²). Lower bound: |f| ≥ 3n² → f = Ω(n²). Both → f = Θ(n²). It's also O(n³) but that's a weaker statement.
f = ω(g) means f grows strictly faster than g — the ratio |f/g| → ∞. It's the opposite of little-o. For example, n² = ω(n) because n²/n = n → ∞.
